You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.

<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of new_connection_close_:
```c
static void
new_connection_close_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                       struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  mhd_assert (connection->daemon == daemon);
  mhd_assert (! connection->in_cleanup);
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->next);
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->nextX);
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->nextE);
#endif /* EPOLL_SUPPORT */

#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  if (NULL != connection->tls_session)
  {
    mhd_assert (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS));
    gnutls_deinit (connection->tls_session);
  }
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  MHD_socket_close_chk_ (connection->socket_fd);
  MHD_ip_limit_del (daemon,
                    connection->addr,
                    connection->addr_len);
  if (NULL != connection->addr)
    free (connection->addr);
  free (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided code fragment. The snippet uses only standard C constructs: function definition, pointers to structs, preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef / #endif), function calls, standard library free(), and macro-like identifiers (mhd_assert, MHD_socket_close_chk_, MHD_ip_limit_del) — none of which in this fragment show any compiler-specific extensions (no __attribute__, no __asm, no typeof, no statement-expressions ({...}), no nested functions, no zero-sized array usage, no #pragma GCC, no extended integer types, etc.).

Note: Some identifiers here are macros or calls (mhd_assert, MHD_socket_close_chk_, MHD_ip_limit_del, gnutls_deinit). Those macros or functions could expand to or call compiler-specific extensions, but the expansions/definitions are not present in this fragment. Because Rule 1.2 requires reporting only when the code uses language compiler extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions, and there is no evidence of such extensions in the shown code, nothing is reported. If the definitions of the macros or other referenced code are provided and contain compiler-specific extensions, those should be re-evaluated.
